page.title: 12DOVER/FOLKESTONE RAIL LINE
page.content: On 17th July we walked part of the Dover to Folkestone railway line,which was described as the "eighth wonder of the World" when it was constructed in the 1840's.The engineers first constructed the then largest brick built viaduct in Folkestone,then had to blow up part of the cliffs which were too unsafe to tunnel through and had to shore up the line throughout its length ,as it runs over a landslip area. In this region the chalk sits on blue gault clay which is gradually being compressed,causing the railway to subside.A 24 hour watch has to be kept on the track and British Rail have now constructed aprons and sea walls to stop further collapse.
